TBK1 is recruited to a number of signaling complexes, resulting in a variety of outcomes other than IFN induction. we used proximity ligation assay and coimmunoprecipitation assay. the leader proteinase of foot-and-mouth disease virus and the PLP2 protein of murine hepatitis virus are both known to block IFN induction by deubiquitinating TBK1. in both cell types, ubiquitinated TBK1 was detected by 4 h after HIV-1 treatment continuing to 24 h. the precise point in the signaling pathway at which HIV-1 blocks IFN induction was defined. several viruses have evolved to block IFN induction by interfering with the TRAF3-TBK1-IRF3 signaling complex via a physical interaction with a virally encoded protein. however, none of these studies have reported a specific interaction of the viral protein with TBK1 but rather that the formation or function of the signaling complex is prevented. reversing the inhibition of IFN- induction by HIV-1 may reduce spread. in mucosal DCs this may restore an early IFN barrier to mucosal HIV-1 penetration by creating a tighter bottleneck. there is substantial productive infection with HIV in (M0) MDMs cultured in human serum in vitro. this is similar to that in ex vivo “resting” microglial cells.
